Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2018 11:49PM anna4969 wrote: There likely is something else in Ketoprofen that is assisting or making the anti-inflammatory benefits more effective in this particular NSAID, as I was taking a fair amount of prescription Ibuprofen and prescription Naproxen, and was not experiencing the same benefits with either or those that I am with the Ketoprofen. So there is something else there. I certainly am mindful of the stomach issues. We are staying on top of kidney lab work every 6 months. You are very correct in the cost difference as my prescriptions of Ibuprofen and Naproxen are minimal, not so with the Ketoprofen.
Posts.Title: Study finds first possible drug treatment for lymphedema cowgal cowgal

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2018 02:46AM anna4969 wrote: I really wonder what drug they are referring to in this study. I know that Dr. Rockson was doing some sort of study with Ketoprofen at some point. Not sure if he is still working on that one. I can tell you that after reading about it last year, I asked my MO about trying a Ketoprofen regiment for my lymphedema that has been quite problematic for 6/7 years. He had the pharmacist call Stanford and inquire on what dosage Dr. Rockson was giving his patients, but they would not reveal this. So he put me on a daily low dose of Ketoprofen in June of last year, and I must say that it is the first time in 6/7 years that I have gotten relief from the pain I constantly had in that arm. My pain is not completely gone, but much improved. It really has made a huge difference. I am grateful for the dedication Dr. Rockson has for this rotten side effect of cancer treatment.
Posts.Title: Study finds first possible drug treatment for lymphedema cowgal cowgal

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2011 01:30AM anna4969 wrote: One more thing to add after I just reread your post.  A mild case, I don't think any case of cellulitis is a mild case.  It most certainly is what prompted the start of my lymphedema.  Not only that, they worry very much about the infection going systemic.  So...Please get another opinion.
Posts.Title: Looks like Lymphedma - Can It Be Cancer Recurrence? hope1 beacher4209

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2011 01:27AM anna4969 wrote: In reading your post and responses, I would certainly think another opinion on the matter is warranted.  I, myself, had cellulitis in late March, was put on oral antibiotics for 14 days.  After the 14 days, I could still feel pain in elbow and was put on another week and 1/2 of oral.  But, I really never 100% felt like it was gone even after 3 1/2 weeks of oral antibiotics.  About two months later, it reared it's ugly head again and this time in the hospital I was put on IV antibiotics.  They used Avelox and then I went home with another 3 weeks of IV antibiotics(Avelox).  That finally kicked it out of my system.  I have heard, too, that cellulitis can be very resistant, so maybe a substantial course of IV antibiotics might be the solution like it was for myself and AnnetteS.  Please let us know how things resolve.  Take care and once you get another opinion you will feel that much better. :)
Posts.Title: Looks like Lymphedma - Can It Be Cancer Recurrence? hope1 beacher4209

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2012 04:28AM anna4969 wrote: Kriserts Wow thanks for these articles and the information.  I am actually headed to Houston for a lymph node transfer and diep procedure at the end of this month.  I wonder if my PS is aware of this new opportunity.  I will certainly have to address this with him.  Though still in the very begining stages, this sounds fantastic.  Thank you, thank you :)
Posts.Title: trials on Lymfactin kriserts kira

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2013 06:10PM anna4969 wrote: Hi Mary625 Yes, Yes!!!  I am so happy to see your post as I am 2 1/2 years out and I still have that very same itching.  It is on the outer two quadrants for me.  I had 18 lymph nodes removed and I wonder if having the lymph nodes removed does have something to do with it.  I had a prophy on the left without removal of lymph nodes and I have yet to have any deep internal itching on that side So??  For me it happens about once every two weeks and lasts for a little less than a day.  I am ready to go crazy, because just like you, it is deep and itching does absolutely nothing to relieve it because that is only topical.  I am also completely numb there as well since the surgery.  I end up slapping my breast in that area hoping it will give me a little relief.  It does not really because it is so internal that nothing can reach it.  I, too, am thinking that this long out, could it still be nerves regenerating?  I wonder. I will be very interested in responses.  Thank you for asking this question.

I will have you in my thoughts and prayers while you conquer this obstacle, and you will. :) anna
Posts.Title: friggin brain biopsy results :< chainsawz AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2011 09:25PM anna4969 wrote: Reesie and Chainsawz Thank you so very, very much for the advice.  The largest of the nodules is 7mm.  My onc is suggesting that we wait until October and rescan and go from there as he is telling me that a lung biopsy is not fun.  Chainsawz, how large were your nodules when they were first found and you insisted on a biopsy that proved to be in your best interest by far?  I am really up in the air about this.  On one hand, I don't want to let things progress if it is mets but on the otherhand I don't know if a lung biopsy is the right thing to with them this small.  Thus I guess all the questions about size and such.  Is the 7mm just too little to biopsy at this point?  I am still on Herceptin until further notice and have been on it for 15 months now.  So not sure if that is providing some insurance or not.  I also have a little unproductive cough but wonder if that isn't the herceptin as I go in stretches with an on and off cough and I'm pretty sure that Herceptin is the culprit.   Any ideas?  Again, the piece of mind that I get from getting advice for all of you who have experienced this, is truly invaluable.  I am grateful. :)
Posts.Title: Looking for my "Lung Mets" sisters.... WingsofHope grammadebbie

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2011 11:26PM anna4969 wrote: Chainsawz Thank you so much for the reply.  Of the 3 new nodules that showed on the ct scan last week, the largest is 7mm.  It is new, not there in all the other numerous ct scans I had because of the 3 stable ones for the past year and a half.  So, as you certainly know, it is concerning that all of a sudden since the last ct scan in December, here we have something new.  Can you tell me about the biopsy?  Isn't it a huge deal with considerable discomfort and recovering time?  My onc is really suggesting that I just wait and rescan in oct. and if they haven't changed then just continue with the next scan in 3 months until they can confirm that they are in fact, benign if no changes.   But we all know how quick things can change because of the her2 factor and so I, like you stated with insisting on a biopsy, don't want anything to be going on covertly while I could have done something about it sooner.  So I am interested in the dirty low down on lung biopsies and what I could expect.  Were yours the 8mm when they biopsied?  Again, thank you for taking the time and giving me the inside experience on what I could expect. :)
Posts.Title: Looking for my "Lung Mets" sisters.... WingsofHope grammadebbie

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2011 10:48PM anna4969 wrote: Reesie Thank you so very much for the reply.  You commented that they are very small.  I am happy about that but wonder if that is, in fact, how they start.  Very, very small and then all of a sudden a growth spurt in them?  Thank you everyone for bearing with me and this question.  I sincerely appreciate it.  :)
Posts.Title: Looking for my "Lung Mets" sisters.... WingsofHope grammadebbie

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2011 10:59PM anna4969 wrote: Hi Sarah Sweety, I love your name!!!  Very cute and warm.  How big were your lung nodules that showed 2 weeks into your diagnosis?  I had a couple that they noted at my diagnosis too, and those are the ones we had been following with the Ct scan, but they have stayed the exact same size.  So they are quite convinced they were not cancer.  Because of those intial nodules, they have continued to scan me every 3 months and that is why these new developments are even known.  How big were your nodules? I will have to give this some more thought on what I can deal with and tolerate should I just simply decide that I need piece of mind and I want them biopsied.  Thank you for responding to me.
Posts.Title: Looking for my "Lung Mets" sisters.... WingsofHope grammadebbie

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2011 09:14PM anna4969 wrote: Hello everyone, I have been looking for some information on lung mets and have read all of your posts.  I just came back from onc and have 3 areas of concern on a ct scan.  They are small 2mm, 4mm and 7mm.  The radiologist's report lists these areas as intermittent atelectasis on 2 of the 3 and the other is listed as a mucoid impaction.  My onc says they are too small to determine if they are cancerous or not and that even a pet scan will not show as they are so small.  The plan is to rescan in 3 months.  I am wondering how you found your lung mets, how small were they when diagnosed, how were they initally diagnosed if not diagnosed as lung mets from the get go and with your experience- is it reasonable to rescan in 3 months and see if these areas have changed or should I be running to the lung oncologist and asking for a biopsy?  I have had a non productive cough for about 2 months and have some middle of the back pain when taking a full breath.  But I should also ad that I have an implant in the rt that has been miserably uncomfortable since last July and I sleep poorly and can never find a position that is comfortable.  I feel like my upper half is always compensating for the miserable tight implant.  Any advice or comments would be wonderful.  Thank you so much for bearing with this long, long question.
Posts.Title: Looking for my "Lung Mets" sisters.... WingsofHope grammadebbie

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2011 10:01PM anna4969 wrote: My scenerio is much like bella, though slightly smaller, 9cm IDC.  I am very close to 2 years post diagnosis.  I did neoadjuvant 4 of FAC, 12 of Taxol & Herceptin, and then continued with Herceptin the rest of the year & 27 rad treatments.  At surgery time, the tumor had melted and only on one slide of many did a couple of  cancerous cells show.  I had mastectomy with ALN dissection. Pathology report confirmed nodes were now all clear and I had 8-9 involved when diagnosed.  Regarding lymphedema, yes, unfortunately I did develop it about 5 months after my last radiation treatment.  It has been a bear, and I am getting consumed with dealing with it. I had uni mastectomy but will be having prophy with diep construction in February by choice. Med. onc said it really is not medically necessary BUT my large tumor never showed on the two mammograms I had but we could feel the enlarged lymph nodes. It stinks it spread to the axillary lymph nodes, but then again that is how I knew something was wrong. Would hate to think about what could have been. I look at it this way, those little lymph nodes were doing their job. Thankgoodness!!! All other scans were clear.  The other reason for having prophy is my mother had breast cancer too, after menopause, hers was er +.  I don't want that one sneaking up on me in the other breast. Once is enough. Be well ladies :)
Posts.Title: Calling All with Tumors 6 cm + J-Bug CaliKelly

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2011 09:23PM anna4969 wrote: Irish Oh yes, absolutely wonderful that you are seeking their medical expertise and pleasant personalities.  I, personally, started a clinical trial with them last December, and have been nothing but happy and feel blessed that I was able to get care at this cancer hospital that has been ranked world wide #1 for the past 7 years.  They are highly intelligent and personable.  The combination that one would certainly seek and expect not what you have been dealing with.  That is just plain unacceptable.  I travel too, from the north and love to go to sunny, warm Houston, a little perk in the whole scheme of things.  Be well :)
Posts.Title: MD Anderson Second Opinion irish22 Timbuktu

Posts.Content: May 1, 2012 01:10PM anna4969 wrote: Yes, this is an ugly place to be always standing on the edge of that cliff hoping and praying that a wind is not at our backs.  Great analogy!!! Laurie, I so hear you.  Like all the wonderful ladies commented above, most of us have that scenerio operating somewhere in our lives.  I, too, have a brother that just doesn't get it.  Even though our mother had breast cancer and our father died of prostate cancer.  I too get angry and upset sometimes with his attitude.  It must be bliss to live in La La land.  Can I go there too?  Then on the otherhand, I think to myself I am so grateful for every soul, including my brother, that has no clue what this all really means because thankfully they are not living it and hopefully never will.  Most days...and of course much, much easier said than done, I just don't allow myself to get too upset by others actions because that stress is too detrimental to me.  We've got enough on our plates to deal with. Take care and know that just about every single one of us, knows what you are feeling. Keeping the Faith.
Posts.Title: Annoyed, need to let it go... Laurie09 karen1956

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2011 08:56PM anna4969 wrote: Hi, I had the very same experience.  Actually by the time I left the er, I could see an improvement.  It took a full two weeks for it to settle down and then I still felt as though it was not completely gone, so called my onc and he ordered another week of oral antibiotics.  Fast forward three weeks from there and, of course on a Sunday night, I layed in bed and felt the same portion of my arm hurt.  Long story short, next day I was in the hospital with iv antibiotics and went home self administering iv antibiotics for another 3 weeks.  It moves very rapidly and can be quite resistant.  Thus the reason for my story.  Be sure you keep an eye on it after this first round of antibiotics and call IMMEDIATELY if you think it has not completely gone away.  I feel the second infection really rapidly progressed this lymphedema, so stay on top of it.  Best of luck with this.
Posts.Title: Cellulitis - any advice? ALittleBitBritish Nunina

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 10:48PM anna4969 wrote: Nannababy, Thank you for that article!!! I am so pleased to read that.  After neoadjuvant and then mastectomy, all my lymph nodes were now clear and about 8-9 were involved to begin with but there was a tiny bit of residual left in the breast tissue.  I was concerned of course, but all my doctors were ecstatic.  Now, I know why.  Thank you. Take care all.
